body.paragraph: A while loop consists of two parts: (a) the repeating condition, and (b) the body of the loop. The body of the loop (indented statements below the while loop) will repeatedly be executed as long as the condition is true and will stop immediately when it becomes False.

body.example:
i = 0
while i < 10:
	print(i)
	i = i + 1

tooltip.title: repeatedly execute code while true
tooltip.body: repeatedly executes the code block inside the while loop as long as the condition remains `True`.

tips.text: the `while` loop in Python compared to the `repeat until` block in Scratch: the `while` loop in Python repeats code as long as the condition is `True`, and stops when the condition becomes `False`. However, the `repeat until` block in Scratch repeats code as long as the condition is `False`, and stops when the condition becomes `True`.

i is no longer less than 3 so the condition is false
should execute the next line after the while loop
